abstract.p: Letter from Frank J Fahrenkopf Jr (American Gaming Association), replies to Jim Calhoun's Sept 27 Op-Ed article supporting legislation to ban legal sports betting in Nevada on college games

block.p: The legislation supported by Jim Calhoun, the head basketball coach at the University of Connecticut, that would ban legal sports betting in Nevada on college games (Op-Ed, Sept. 27) would do nothing to curb the illegal gambling and ''multitude of gambling pressures'' that he worries about. Only 1 percent of all sports betting is done legally in Nevada. Far more is wagered illegally on University of Connecticut games in Connecticut than legally in Nevada.

The legislation supported by Jim Calhoun, the head basketball coach at the University of Connecticut, that would ban legal sports betting in Nevada on college games (Op-Ed, Sept. 27) would do nothing to curb the illegal gambling and ''multitude of gambling pressures'' that he worries about. Only 1 percent of all sports betting is done legally in Nevada. Far more is wagered illegally on University of Connecticut games in Connecticut than legally in Nevada.
The legislation would also do nothing to eliminate point spreads from appearing in newspapers, on the Internet and in other sources easily accessible to students.

Let's focus on the real problem: finding out why sports wagering remains so pervasive despite a 1992 law against it in most states and developing real solutions that aren't aimed at the only state in which sports wagering is regulated, policed and taxed.
FRANK J. FAHRENKOPF JR. President and Chief Executive American Gaming Association Washington, Oct. 6, 2000
